Morgan Freeman is...well, Morgan Freeman who never disappoints.  But Helen Mirren, a bread-and-breakfast flowering arranging, meal planning, elder is also a deadly assassin who loves to kill people.  She's also in love with their Russian adversary who has always wanted to kill a U.S. President, played by highly versatile Brian Cox.

This is a movie not intended to be taken too seriously.  The big guns and big explosions often had me laughing out loud at times because the characters take the action very seriously, and you can't help but laugh at the old Western-like face offs. See this movie for the unbelievable cast, and for its hilarity.

Bruce Willis followers won't be disappointed, although Bruce's character is a bit reserved this time. There's not a lot of classic emotional connection in the storyline between you and the characters or with between the characters themselves, but that's okay.  You'll still walk away like you've just had a great day at an amusement park.

I'd give it 4 stars for entertainment value, 4 stars for action, and 3 stars for writing and plot.

The best thing about this movie is the subtle but funny dialogues. For example, when Bruce Willis asked Helen Mirren "Aren't you bored of the retirement life?". She answered "No, I enjoyed it. I do take the odd contract on the side". She meant sometimes she took a contract to kill somebody! There are other dialogues that are far more tickling but I don't want to spoil the movie by revealing them here.
I prefer this kind of jokes than the in-your-face one.

There are also a lot of actions.

In short, it's hilariously entertaining and it deserves 4 stars. I own it.

Bruce Willis is back doing what he does best: action-comedy. The movie opens with Willis getting up as the clock turns to 6:00 AM with no alarm. This quick opening scene shows us his orderly life. He rips up his retirement checks just so he can talk to a woman in Kansas City on the phone, whom he has not met, but has a fascination. Played by Marie-Louise Parker she also writes bad spy romances which Willis reads. As Willis gets up too early, his sixth sense is working, a group of men attempt to kill him. He heads to KC and kidnaps his would-be gf. As it turns out the CIA is trying to kill him for something that happened in Guatemala in 1981. The bulk of the movie is to figure out why and to stop it before they get killed.

The dialouge has a dry wit to it. For example when Willis takes a bullet:

Parker: "This is bad."
Willis: "People get shot all the time."
Parker: "No they don't. They normally get paper cuts."
Malkovich: "I normally get shot."

The film moves at a good pace and really gets fun when Malkovich shows up. John was a former CIA operative who was given LSD everyday for 11 years. He is quirky and paranoid.

Ernest Borgnine: Plays a CIA records keeper.
Karl Urban: CIA agent hunting Willis.
Morgan Freeman: Former CIA agent, part of Willis' group.
Helen Mirren: Also a former "wet" agent. Retired and complex. She enjoys baking, arranging flowers, and killing.
Richard Dreyfuss shows up near the end as a bad guy arms dealer.

As in most modern action films, impossible things happen. But then that is what makes them fun to watch and we all expect it from a Willis film.

The word "red" is an acronym describing the Bruce Willis character, a retired CIA operative, who remains extremely dangerous. Willis telephones Mary-Louis Parker, a CIA financial clerk, frequently and is attracted to her. He is surprisingly attacked suddenly by a group who try to kill him. But Willis is no ordinary retired operative and is very competent in combat. He overcomes his attackers.

 He realizes that the CIA, or some element in the organization, wants to kill him. He understands that the attackers will go after Mary because of his many telephone calls to her. He discovers that other CIA operatives, all associated with one particular mission, have been killed. Despite his abilities, he needs help to find who specifically is trying to kill him and his associates and why.

 He rescues Mary and gets help from past CIA operatives who were on the mission: Morgan Freeman, an eighty-year old man living in a nursing home and dying of cancer; John Malkovich, whose mind has been somewhat fried because of his involvement in LSD government experiments: and Helen Mirren, who is a good medic and an expert marksman. He also seeks aid from a past Russian rival, a friend of Helen Mirren.

 The plot of the film and its quirky characters have been in many movies, but Red offers very good actors, minor twists in the tale, as well as many comedic elements, that make the film enjoyable.

This movie is great, it had a stellar cast, and was very funny. All the characters were great and it was well written. I really enjoyed this film. Films based on government conspiracies are usually dry and not funny this film breaks the mold.

This movie was everything I had hopped the Expendables was going to be! A fun movie that handles aging action stars the right way. A good story with excellent actors doing what they do best. Just the right combination of humor and action. Bruce Willis really knows how to have a good time in front of the camera and he let's the audience share the moment.

I love the movie.  It is a very funny, classic movie.  Very well done.  I would recommend this movie to everyone.  One of the best movies ever made.  Love the fight scene, the actors were at the top of there game.

What is the line on Mary-Louise Parker's teeth????  You can see when she smiles while talking on the phone in RED, it goes horizontally across all the maxillary teeth about 1/3 of the way up the visible portion.  It is light blue.  It doesn't look like Invisalign trays, & I doubt tetracycline stain since most celebrities would just get veneers (whitening tetra. stain is expensive & unpredictable) .... any ideas?

The movie was fantastic!  Explosions, big phallic guns, physically impossible action, unbelievable escape scenarios, true love, and crazy eccentric characters made it a fun fantasy joy ride.  I'm going to buy it right now.

It's just driving us nuts trying to figure out what's on Ms. Parker's teeth!

4.3 stars

It's good that Hollyweird is slowly realizing some of the most ingenious writers working are writing "comic books". They have been for decades, in fact, and Red makes the case for their many skills quite well. This script is excellent, with many many very funny lines and set-ups. The direction is likewise solid, and every actor here is clearly having a great time and taking none of it too seriously. Malkovich especially proves again and again that he is one of the most underrated comic actors around; between this and Burn After Reading you've got to give the guy serious props.

We laughed a lot and were entertained throughout Red. It's nice and tight and doesn't go on too long, and in general Red is one of the more enjoyable action/comedies I've seen in a long time. The blu-ray transfer is very very crisp, and made the outstanding effects and interesting shots/angles even more fun to watch.

If you're looking for an action-filled flick with fine acting and tongue firmly in cheek, this one is for you.

I love Bruce Willis, so I knew this had to be a good movie...and it was, there was plenty of Action and Comedy...the best combination ever Morgan F. and John M. were great also...it was just a great combination of people.  You know sometimes how you watch those movies with too many popular people in it, and it just doesn't work...well, this isn't one of those movies...it's wonderful! :)

We loved this movie. It was witty and very dry. Helen Mirren is the actor who made me want to watch this movie. It was refreshing to see a kick ass, deadly lady. I loved it that the fight scenes were abrupt and surprising. It makes me nuts to watch a movie where the fight scenes go on and on with the same punches and the enemy gets up and walks away. These personalities are very effective. I loved the scene at the airport. I laughed at the absurdity. Great movie!

I realize that age is a definite factor in this movie so I suppose I'm biased in its favor simply on the basis of being of "a certain age" (just slightly younger than Helen Mirren in fact). I'd like to think that's not the only reason I found it a frolicking good film, filled with lots of humor and no graphic violence (just the over-the-top comic book variety). It's smart, well written and has a stellar cast who pull off the whole thing with straight faces! I had a ... well, a blast!

As much as I love Warren Ellis, his comic RED (with art by Cully Hammer) wasn't one of my favorites from him.  Red the film on the other hand is a surprisingly enjoyable and breezy comedic action flick that boasts an impressive cast and sharp production values; all of which culminates in a surprisingly good comic adaptation.  Bruce Willis stars as retired CIA badass Frank Moses who, along with his would-be prospective girlfriend (Mary-Louise Parker) becomes targeted by his former employers.  Soon enough, Frank enlists the help of some old friends and allies (Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich, Helen Mirren, and Brian Cox) as he dodges the determined young agent (Karl Urban) who is hot on his tail.  The breezy nature of Red is what makes it so worthwhile, along with the big-name cast of old pros (which also includes Richard Dreyfus and Ernest Borgnine) who are enjoying every moment of their time here.  All in all, Red is a surprisingly fun comic adaptation that is whole-heartedly worth your time.

RED is great for older people! RED is great for middle-aged people! RED is great for young professionals! RED is great for late teens! In other words, anyone who likes action movies will LOVE RED!

The comedy intertwined with the drama makes this a fun watch. Don't expect Oscar material though... unlike Black Swan, for example, RED is enjoyable and well-acted!

This is an insult, it really is.  If there was no DVD of Red out there, and no special edition with everything, then ok, maybe they get away with this.  But to deliberately put out this hacked version and not make it PAINFULLY OBVIOUS what you are getting...that is just low.  I have no problem with the idea of having tiered levels of pricing for what you get (though I have to question the wisdom for everybody of having say, 3 different Blu Ray sku's for toy story 3), and even lo-res audio would be ok if it is CLEAR what you are getting...if you were being given an informed choice. And if the ONLY difference was audio, then you'd make an informed decision vs. the special edition, but no, it appears that its the other stuff that differentiates the two versions. It's just obviously and intentionally deceptive.  My goodness, people who opt for Blu-Ray vs DVD want the whole deal for crying out loud...deceptive I tell ya!

There are two things you should know before watching "Red." The action-packed film is nominated for Golden Globe best picture for comedy/musical category (and this is not definitely a musical). The other thing is that the action comedy has great players including four Oscar winners (Ernest Borgnine, Richard Dreyfuss, Morgan Freeman and Helen Mirren). With this stellar cast, things just can't go wrong.

The story itself, loosely based on the graphic novel created by Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner, is not original. A retired CIA agent Frank Moses (Bruce Willis), now living alone, is suddenly attacked by a heavily armed hit squad. To survive and uncover who is pulling the strings, Frank goes to New Orleans, tracking down the clues while being chased by the current CIA agent William Cooper (Karl Urban) bent on killing him.

Bruce Willis is fine as the retired agent who hasn't lost his touch, but it is Mary-Louise Parker as Sarah, an unsuspecting customer service agent for Moses' pension (and possible love interest), and John Malkovich as Marvin Boggs, ex-spy and conspiracy theorist, who steal every scene they are in. Plus, Helen Mirren firing a machine gun is something you shouldn't miss.

Obviously the film greatly benefits from the talents of the players, who seem having fun. The direction of Robert Schwentke (Flightplan, The Time Traveler's Wife) is not particularly inspired, and the wrap-up is too neat and tidy like the Jodie Foster thriller, but the director keeps the ball rolling throughout. "Red" is a light-footed action comedy that refuses to be taken too seriously, and is enjoyable as such.

This is a cracker of a movie.  Just the thing after watching very serious movies taking on very worthy and serious subjects.  This was fun, lots and lots of fun.  All I can say is that if you want to take a couple of hours off and enjoy yourself this film is for you.  Every actor carries his or her weight and the storyline is fantastic.  I was looking forward to the DVD as I did not catch it at the movies.  It did not disappoint.  Hope they make another this was a blast.
I 'am sorry but this movie was just boring to me  just could not get into this movie  great actors but bad movie to bad lot of good actors and actress in this movie.

After all the CG c...p, it's good to have one of these 2 hour diversions with proven actors/actresses comfortably going thru their paces with no effort.  Willis and Freeman are reunited after being in a similar type of film (Lucky Slevin, which is also good), although Freeman don't get to do much in this film. Malkovich, whom I enjoy immensely hams it up along with Mirren.  Not much to the story - just relax and watch the pros do their thing.

Frank Moses (Bruce Willis) retired form the CIA is just trying to make time over the phone with Sarah Ross (Mary-Louise Parker) when to his chagrin he finds he is the target of unfinished business and anyone he likes may be dispatched along with himself. Now he must find the culprits or cabal that is out to depose of him and a hand full of other CIA retirees known as RED's (Retired and Extremely Dangerous) this will require getting the band back together.

Watch and have fun as the impossible becomes possible and you cannot help saying "Stay in the car". Of course Bruce Willis played in a lot of action shoot-um-up movies but Helen Mirren may soon surpass him. I know the movie is not unique but who cares? It is just fun to want them act it out.

I was pretty skeptical of this movie and not really sure what to expect. There are alot of long time (good) actors in this movie that let you just get right into the movie. The action just comes out of nowhere and is fantastic. There is a chase scene that involves Bruce Willis that has a moment in it that just wowed me and my wife.

I would say this movie stands up to repeated watches and you can take more stuff away on future watches.

I wasn't sure about this movie when I went to the theater, but fell in love five minutes in. Action, guns, explosions, and comedy? It doesn't get any better than that. John Malkovich's character was my favorite.

This movie is well acted and believe it or not....suspenseful while being hilarious in many scenes!  We were all extremely pleased with all the actors performances and the storyline too!  I would definitely recommend it. (PS-The storyline doesn't seem THAT far fetched considering the CIA we are learning about)

(No spoilers)

We enjoyed it, loved the cast - we found the movie quirky and humorous, different from anything else we've ever seen, held our interest, and we had a good time watching it.  Some things were predictable and some so off-the-wall no one could predict.

I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a different type of movie, it doesn't quite fall into any one category like action, adventure, fantasy, or romantic comedy, but is a little bit of all the above.  Yes, we'd watch it again.  It was great getting to see John Malkovich again after recently viewing Secretariat...we LOVED the pig!  John is always such an intriguing actor.  It was lovely to see Mary-Louise Parker whom I haven't seen since Fried Green Tomatoes, well played here as well, and she doesn't look like she's aged a bit!

I'm glad this title came up in the most viewed VODs, thanks Amazon & fellow viewers.  :)

Great movie, highly recommended!

However, this Blu-ray does not carry a lossless audio track (mentioned in other reviews), and Amazon uses the same description for other Blu-rays which DO have Lossless audio.  Amazon's Description states:

Format: AC-3, Color, Dolby, Subtitled, Widescreen

If you go to the page for The Dark Knight [Blu-ray], you will see the EXACT same description -- Word for word!  And The Dark Knight DOES have a Dolby True HD Lossless soundtrack.  Since lossless is standard on the majority of Blu-rays, and they Amazon the same description for Blu-rays carrying lossless audio, this leads consumers to believe the Red Blu-ray also has lossless audio.

I have returned this (opened) Blu-ray for a refund, citing "Different From Web Site Description" as the reason.  Since other Blu-rays with lossless Dolby True HD audio carry the exact same description, this is a legitimate reason for full refund.

Amazon needs to review their policy and start giving more accurate descriptions of their Blu-rays.
I almost fell asleep... Acting was HORRIBLE and the plot was non-existent. I cannot believe they cast so many great stars for such a dumb movie. What a waste of talents!!!!
This was a great movie. Moves quickly and is enjoyable. For a light, enjoyable movie, this is a great choice. If you are a Bruce Willis fan, it is definitely worth seeing.

I didn't know what to expect with this movie when I sat down to watch it. I found the story to be engaging and funny. The action was awesome and kept me fascinated with some of the action they did. It is a very fun story and I highly recommend watching this movie. I actually have bought it so if you are considering buying it-BUY IT. You will love the movie!
This Movie is the Best. Its so Funny. Its just one of those movies you can watch over and over.

Short Attention Span Summary:

1. Spy is in love with a girl.
2. Bad Guys from government want to kill the protagonist.
3. Spy rounds up a bunch of ex spy friends to uncover the plot.
4. Spy kidnaps Vice President and forces him to admit the plot.
5. Spy leaves with girl, and another romance between two other characters is rekindled.

The fact that this plot was so implausible didn't bother me all that much (after all, that's why it's a movie). And there is a limit to how bad anything Morgan Freeman is in can be. But on the other hand, the characters in this movie just weren't well developed. What is quite the word for when
a bunch of first class actors are thrown together in something that is supposed to be funny (but somehow misses the mark)? I could have used a bit more time developing the relationship between the Bruce Willis protagonist and his love interest.
I would not buy this movie new. Some of the things just came out of nowhere, and I got the impression that they were just lashed onto the end to make the whole thing work. It will be on the second hand shelf soon enough (or at the dollar store).

I love love loved it it was fun action pack and a hint of humor. RED (Retired Extremely Dangerous) that pretty much describe Bruce alright . Not much to say but the minute they came to Bruce house and try to kill him the movie had me since that moment. If your a Bruce Willis fan then you won't be disappointed and of course his other co stars. Best way to describe it it's like Ocean's twelve meets Die Hard.

When the actors in this has been accomplish as they have with all having a great and impressive resume it's good to see them let Lose and have fun with a good fun, humor action movie.

Someone wants Frank Moses (Bruce Willis), retired CIA/assassin, dead. Now living a very uneventful life, Frank finds solace and companionship with Sarah (Mary Louise Parker), a seemingly bored customer service representative. Monthly he uses the excuse of his checks being issued in the wrong amount to work his way into her life. After an attempt is made on his life, the unknown enemy decides to kidnap his new love interest and use her for bait, which inevitably turns in a game of cat and mouse. Determined to rescue her and discover the truth, Moses visits other retired agents seeking their help. And what a group of talented actors, who each brought an authentic quality to their roles (with the exception of one that I will mention later). Joe (Morgan Freeman) is living in a retirement home, literally dying and this seems to be an opportunity for some last minute fun. Victoria (Helen Miran) is enjoying her life as a simple woman (who once put three bullets thru the man she loved simply because the agency wanted her to) and would remind you of a loveable but deadly grandmother. Paranoid, conspiracy theorist Marvin (played by the delightful John Malkovich) is only to willing to show Moses how the present events are related to a past transgression of someone they know.  Ivan (Brian Cox) is simply willing to spend time with the woman who he has never stopped loving, even if she shot him (3 times) and left him for dead. There is the devoted and dedicated CIA Agent who will stop at nothing to get his man. And finally, there is the very shady Alexander (Richard Dreyfuss) who is not what he appears, and who believes that he single handedly has created the Vice President (Julian McMahan) who is destined to be President. Both are willing to stop at nothing in an effort to protect a secret. Eventually, Moses figures out why they all have been scheduled for elimination and works hard to reveal the truth.

I thought that this was a decent movie with a great cast. However, I did struggle with the final rating and ended up giving this movie a 3.5 to 4. I tend to rate it higher because the fabulous actors made me overlook the defects in the storyline. The only character that I was never sure about was that of Sarah. I kept thinking that the final twist should have been that she was an agent meant to seduce Moses but also learn the truth (or something...more), instead she just seemed a little too simple lacking the same depth that the other characters. She moved from wanting to get away, to falling into line wanting to participate in a dangerous adventure. I don't know, she was the only character that I really didn't like, which was hard since she was the center of the storyline. Perhaps another actress would have made the character more likeable for me. Anyway, I definitely would recommend this for someone who is looking for just the right amount of humor and adventure.

RED is just simply a fun movie with a fun cast.  The plot is corny and the action sequences are over-the-top but the movie doesn't try and make you take these things seriously.  Not for those looking for a serious action/espionage movie (think Bourne Identity).

This is the CIA's version of Space Cowboys. You have a group of old, retired agents who are thrust back into action in order to solve a conspiracy.

Red stands for Retired, Extremely Dangerous. It stars a stellar cast of greats: Bruce Willis, John Malkovich, Helen Mirren, Karl Urban and Morgan Freeman.

Bruce Willis is a lonely ex-agent who finds himself in the cross-hairs of a special wet team. Wanting help, he grabs his old team, Malkovich, Mirren and Freeman, in order to discover who wants them killed and why.

Karl Urban plays the CIA agent in charge of their disposal.

There are some wonderful action moments and John Malkovich is as funny as ever. He is the best part of this movie by far.

I felt jilted by the Morgan Freeman character - or at least how his character was dealt with.

It almost feels like watching the 80s version of Bruce Willis and his movies of that decade where there's serious explosions with a high mix of laughs while they don't quite take themselves seriously.

This is a terrific movie to rent for a weekend.

Bottom line...DO NOT BUY if you are an audiophile. This "cheap" version of RED does NOT contain DTS-HD MASTER 5.1 audio. It is only a Dolby Digital 5.1 mix. The more expensive version has the DTS-HD MASTER audio mix.

Sorry people. I did not see the movie. i just want people to know who care about the audio/video to know what they are getting cause this small but big matter (to some people) is not really known. i just wanted to inform people.

This is a great action movie, and the kind you'd expect from Bruce Willis.  If you're looking for something like The Departed, then, no, this isn't the movie for you.  I really can't understand why any of the previous reviewers saw fit to complain that this wasn't an in-depth, emotionally driving story.
It's an ACTION MOVIE, and it's GOOD.  The fight scene between Franks and Cooper alone was worth it, and that's just about the midway point of the movie.  John Malkovich was hilarious, Helen Mirren was perfect as always, Brian Cox was a surprise, as I didn't know he was in it, but he was great, too.  Karl Urban was a real selling point in this movie and just further proves that Karl Urban needs to be in more movies, preferably physically assaulting the crap out of someone.

Look, it's an action movie, it's good, and John Malkovich has a stuffed pig.
Watch the movie.

RED is an excellent movie, as most other reviews will tell you.  I am mainly leaving this review to let everyone know that the special edition extras are not worth paying for.

- The deleted and extended scenes are mostly just slightly longer versions of what is already in the movie and are not very interesting or funny.

- The trivia track is a major let down.  Instead of fun behind the scenes trivia about the movie, you get some random facts that are remotely related to what is going on onscreen.  It's almost like at the last minute they decided they needed a trivia track and so they had some high school kid grab words from the movie and google them.  Seriously, here's one of the first ones -" the color red supposedly makes people hungry."  Very lame.

- There is a section that interviews some of the talent, but they pretty much just gush about how great it was to work with the other cast members.  There is no cool info about how they filmed anything or where, or how any of the special effects were done.

- The inside the CIA feature is also very basic last minute stuff.  They detail several things from leaked CIA documents.

The bottom line is that the movie is excellent and worth buying, but the extras are very poorly conceived and executed.  Either they forgot about extras until the last minute and decided they could get a few more dollars by adding some or they are planning on coming out with a super special edition that actually has some decent content.  Save your money and skip the special edition.

Golden Globe nominated for best comedy.  In truth, it's an action comedy in which you get that the picture isn't trying to take itself too seriously.  A lot of "well aged" actors and actresses who are or were "A" list are in this picture which bumps up the quality some.  Humor is over the top and some of the "A" list people are not in their typical roles.  The love interest wasn't to my liking but she worked enough to pass the bar.  CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B; STORY/PLOTTING: B;
HUMOR: B to B plus; ZANINESS: B; OVERALL GRADE: B; WHEN WATCHED: 01/30/2011.

I went to see this film in the theater with several friends. The cast was amazing, the character developement believable. There was never a dull moment from beginning to end. The dialog was extremely clever and it would be a hard job to figure out who was the actual star of the film. John Malkovich was hillarious and loveable (loveable? Malkovich?... yeah!), Bruce Willis delivered his usual sterling performance as a tough guy with a boyish charm, Helen Mirren was perfect as the Martha Stewart of hitwomen, and Morgan Freeman was, as always, an understated yet powerful character.
The only thing I would have changed would have been to add at least 30 more minutes to the movie, there was so much action it seemed like the opening credits had just finished when the end credits started rolling.
I'm really hoping for a follow up!!!

I love all the actors/actresses in this movie, but it disappointed.  If the movie was a little more in depth and had more acting it would have been alright.  The characters look like they are just talking not acting.  I don't do movie reviews unless it was awesome or terrible.  Well this one was pretty darn bad.  Glad I didn't waste a bunch of money on it.

It is not the first time I have bought a blu-ray title in a bare bones edition. I got no extras, just the movie with the highest audio and quality pictures available. And I was more than happy with that. However, with "RED", a bare bones edition also means NO lossless audio, just your dvd-average dolby digital audio track. And I find this unacceptable. I do not blame Summit for this but Amazon.com. I feel cheated, like a second-class customer or something like it. The movie itself is not great, but it is lots of fun. If you have the money, do not waste it on this edition. Shame on Amazon.com.

Amazing movie. Just saw it over the weekend at Amazon VOD with no idea about this movie, ordered cause I felt the preview was nice and I was blown out with the movie. Highly recomended to watch it atleast once.

Fantastic Action, Brilliant Actors, a simple story but put very well. It's a big screen movie.
This movie will blow your socks off.  It is HILARIOUS.  My wife peed the bed she was laughing so hard. It was out of control! Ashton Kutchers dad was so funny.

In this barebones edition, Summit decided to give us only lossy Dolby Digital, not DTS Master Audio,
 which is on the 2 disc special edition. I ordered this movie because of the low price and when I received the movie today, I was upset about the inferior audio on this disc. If I knew about the difference in audio, I would not have purchased this movie and would have waited for the price to drop on the 2 disc special edition. I am writing this review to help warn other audiophiles about this stupid decision by Summit. The rental discs at Netflix and Blockbuster will also have the inferior audio. You have been warned!
This movie was a MAJOR disappointment - great cast, terrible screenplay.  NO meat to this story.  It relied solely on the draw of the ensemble cast.  I feel bad for them that the story was so thin.
then you will not be disappointed.  This is simply a great action flick, with a lot of humor.  A great cast and huge fun.  My wife and I both enjoyed this.

RED is my favorite movie of 2010. I didn't know what to expect but since I love Bruce Willis, I gave it a try and am definitely happy I did! The action was artfully balanced with humor (Bruce Willis vacuuming!)as a suspenseful plot unfolds that actually had me on the edge of my seat in spots. Watch for the Karl Urban fight scene and Richard Dreyfuss as a rich sleezeball. Ernest Borgnine rounded out a sparkling cast in a couple of brief appearances. The only disappointment was the limited role of the ever cool, calm, and collected Morgan Freeman but this was was offset wonderfully by John Malkovich's hysterical antics.

The RED cast is free of female action figure stereotypes.  Both Helen Mirren and Mary-Louise Parker participate fully, each in their own manner, and yet never loose their warmth and femininity. Even the agent who faces off with John Malkovich in one scene is "real".  Refreshingly, there is no "sexploitation" in RED.

This is a movie the entire family can (and should) watch together. Simply put, it's pure entertainment.

If you like a mix of action and comedy, this movie is a good bet.  While the story line is a bit of a stretch, following former CIA agent Frank Moses out of retirement and teaming up with his old gang to find out who is out to kill them is a pure joy.  A lot of the humor is dry, but works well with the story. There is plenty of action and shooting as well as humorous situations they gang finds themselves in.  I am definately recommending this movie.
I'm not a big movie person, but this was the best $$ I've spent in a long time.  John Malkovich is superb!
As always, a GREAT Bruce Willis movie, with a great cast. Hope they make another movie ( RED 2 ) or one like it

The action violence seems overdone to me in this film, with thousands of bullets being fired, several explosions, and so on.  However, it is worth watching for the sheer entertainment value, and the casting is great--especially of John Malkovich as an operative who is just chock-full of nutty goodness and some justified paranoia.

It is really wild to see Helen Mirren gunning people down and wearing combat boots with a formal gown!
Good mixture of comedy, drama and action between some great well-known acting veterans.  If you like action movies this is for you.

What happens when you are an ex-CIA agent? With all the knowledge of worl government secrets is it all about haning up your gear and moving on to a happy retirement? Apparently not in the film RED. Bruce Willis playes a retired agent who is suddenly a target for termination by the very people who employed him and they will stop at nothing to see him dead. Even if that means getting your butt kicked many times over by the guy you are instructed to kill.

RED is an entertaining hysterical ride. The cast is awesome, getting some of the most well known drama/action stars of the past 25-30 years to fill the roles of government assigned assasins in their golden years is nothing short of brilliant. Morgan Freemen delivers priceless one liners, John Malkovich is flat out hysterical and Helen Mirren....well all I can say is holy bejezus! Of course I have to say the rest of the cast was great. Karl Urban is really showing us that he is a great actor post LOTR. He does exceptionally well in these comic book adaption films and now it has been announced he will be playing Judge Dredd in the much needed re-dux. Brian Cox and Mary-Louise Parker also did a great job, though I didn't expect anything less. Probably the biggest surprise was Richard Dryfus...just because I haven't seen him in a movie in like FOREVER!

All and all, RED is a fun film based on a comic book. I have it on DVD and it is definitely one of the few I will enjoy watching many times over.

How on earth do these ex-CIA agents fit into normal life ? Their idea of friendship,family life, dating and other every activities are out of sync amidst this unnecessary business of getting old. To make matters bad the side they have been on is trying to get them or is someone else putting them up to it ? One thing for sure they couldn't have picked a better cast to play these characters. A very fun film to see.

I just finished watching "Red" and I loved it.  I rented it here on Amazon VOD and I am considering going to buy the Blue Ray for keeps.  It is not often that I finish watching a movie and I want to see it again.  The action was great.  There were twists, surprises and laughs.  Predictable, some parts, but it didn't take away from the movie at all.  I wasn't familiar with this movie before watching it but I'm so glad I chose to watch, it really made my night.

Shouldn't stir up a hornet's nest, that's just asking for it. Frank Moses is a retired CIA wet works operative trying to fit a normal, if lonely, life in the 'burbs. But when Frank reaches out to a bored federal pension service representative named Sarah, when he tries to step out of his hermit's existence, somewhere in the paranoid bowels of the CIA, a red flag goes up. One dark night a CIA-sanctioned hit squad invades Frank's home. Frank Moses's top secret personal dossier is stamped "RED" - for "Retired, Extremely Dangerous." They should've brought more hit squads.

And now Frank Moses is all sorts of curious as to why a kill team was deployed against him. Off he goes looking for answers, low profile all shot to pieces.

If you've read Warren Ellis's repressively bleak, gritty comic book RED, this movie adaptation'll surprise you some. With an eye towards a more audience-friendly product, the screenplay expands on and switches it up some from the original source. Three things stand out immediately and notably. The tone is more lighthearted, tongue-in-cheeky, and not as violent. Sarah (Mary-Louise Parker, really good) - who this time isn't Moses's case handler - achieves more camera time. And, unlike in the comic book in which he's strictly a lone wolf, Moses has a team to assemble. Or as Morgan Freeman's 80-year-old, liver-cancered rest home retiree remarks: "Well, we're getting the band back together. That's nice." And maybe you can't teach old dogs new tricks. But these old dogs have perfected what tricks they do have. Today's CIA asshats have a job and a half trying to curb these - to steal a phrase from Holly Golightly - "mean REDs."

The absolutely top notch cast is what makes this film so much fun to watch. It's worth the price of admission just to see terrific old pros like Willis, Freeman, John Malkovich, and Helen Mirren at play. These actors create a marvelous synergy. They even sort of channel that old Rat Pack cool. Bruce Willis still has the chops to pull of that action leading man role. And, to quote Warren Ellis: "Who wouldn't want to see Helen Mirren with a sniper rifle?" One of the most amusing tidbits divulged in the special features is that Mirren patterned her assassin character after the immaculate Martha Stewart. Karl Urban, fresh off knocking everyone's socks off as the re-imagined Dr. McCoy in STAR TREK, makes a credible - and even likable - antagonist. More old far+s get dusted off for cameos, such as Ernest Borgnine as the CIA's venerable records keeper and Richard Dreyfuss as a sleazy CEO of a defense contract company.

RED, with its brisk cross-country jaunts and its root-for-the-badasss-geriatrics theme and its consistently entertaining beats, is also just off-kiltered enough to make it seem fresh. There's this light capery touch which graces even the film's most generic shoot-'em-up sequences. Given the caliber of the cast, RED would've had to work overtime to stink up the joint. As it is, it certainly made enough of a killing at the box office that a sequel is in the works.

Of course, it's no Love's Savage Secret.

The Special Edition DVD's bonus features: audio commentary by retired CIA Field Officer and RED consultant Robert Baer who gives revealing insights regarding the film's plausibility (and implausibility); 10 Deleted & Extended Scenes, including a funny scene which supplements the film's closing moments of Frank and Marvin on a mission in Moldova (00:08:49 minutes long); an optional running RED trivia track in text captions throughout the film: "Cast Insights" - 14 segments covering topics such as set and location shoots, action sequences, the awesomeness of the cast, and even Helen Mirren's Georgio Armani purse (totaling 00:29:15 minutes); and "CIA Exposed" - disclosing past, previously secret CIA operations, including one project which focused on experimentation with cats (totaling 00:05:59 minutes).

Not much to say, it's probably been reviewed to death and you are wondering if this is going to be a spoiler.

it's not your typical Bruce Willis movie, but then what is? humorous like Mr and Mrs Smith, but don't think i am comparing the two. two intirely different movies. I am just saying you like one you will probably like the other.

four old CIA agents are targeted becuase they were in the wrong place at the wrong time and now someone wants them out of the way. bring in an aging russian agent and you have a geritol hit squad.

funny at times. you still have to suspend beliefe most of the time.

The amount of action and thrill carries the movie alone.  The mix in of cute/funny romance, John Malkovich's character and create lines make this movie one of my favorite all-time action films that will be watch time and time again.

I purchased the Movie Only Edition since I was only interested in the movie and not the extras.  Really, NO HD AUDIO TRACK?

I suppose the people in Summit Entertainment's marketing department thought they were clever when they came up with the idea of a blu-ray high definition movie coupled with a compressed dolby 5.1 soundtrack.  People do not pay close enough attention to the available audio tracks when purchasing a blu-ray for it to have an influence on their decision between buying the regular or the special edition of the movie.  It is assumed that any new release will include either Dolby TrueHD or DTS-HD Master audio.  The marketing tactic isn't causing people to spend the extra money for the special edition to get the HD audio, it is just upseting them when they discover that they have been cheated by Summit and purchased a blu-ray with compressed audio.

For the consumers that moved to blu-ray for the video and audio improvements, you'll only fool us once.  I know I'll be reading the blu-ray.com reviews closely and keeping an eye on this in the future.  I know I definitely will not be buying anything from Summit in the future

This movie was great to watch!  I had so much fun, the action and the good funny lines made it worth it. Ms Helen Mirren is very good in her role, and John Malkovich is simply hilarious.
I recommend this film if you like light humor with action adventure.
This is a very good movie no blood splishing all over the place heads cut off and so on, Just a good entraining movie.

Worst movie I've seen in awhile - and I'm counting the movies on LMN.  It's predictable, corny, and boring.  The first 1/4 of the movie seemed somewhat tolerable, but it never got any better.  I'd rather be stuck in traffic for 3 hours than watch this movie again.

ACTION, INTRIQUE, LAUGHS and romance - it comes in fast and furious in "RED," a sassy, non-formulaic spy caper based on the DC graphic novel by award-winning writer Warren Ellis.

"RED" translates to "Retired, Extremely Dangerous," a term used for the CIA operatives played by Bruce Willis, Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich and Helen Mirren. Just don't call them "old" as that's liable to set them off - especially Malkovich, a very paranoid conspiracy theorist. Still, it's an old mission that brings in a team of current agents to take out the REDs. Dead men and women tell no tales, right?

Adding to the superb chemistry is Karl Urban, Mary-Louise Parker, Ernest Borgnine, Richard Dreyfuss and Brian Cox. But you'll want to keep an eye on Malkovich and Mirren who steal every scene they're in.

"RED" looks and sounds great on Blu-ray. The HD transfer provides a sharp and color-rich picture with a fine layer of film grain. Detail is exceptional, especially in facial expressions/skin tones, clothing and location shots. The sense of depth is theater quality. An uncompressed soundtrack highlights dialogue and quips; effects, such as gunshots and explosions, fill the speaker - all in perfect balance.

Film consultant and retired CIA field officer Robert Boer's commentary tops a list of standard extras (extended/deleted scenes and "Access: RED," a pop-up feature with interviews, documentary shorts and more CIA analysis). He'll keep you listening while detailing what's real and what's not in the film and sharing his experiences such as, "When you return from an assassination attempt on Saddam Hussein and find the FBI waiting to arrest you, it's time to retire."

By the way, he says there's no such CIA category as RED - but maybe there should be!

This movie caught our eye when it was in the theater.  The list of actors is very impressive.  These are actors who can each make a movie, and there are a lot of them.  The idea of the movie, retired people coming back to work their jobs, is alluring to the baby boomers who are retiring in droves.  And lots of guns and action is what movies are so very good at. Somehow, we never did end up seeing the movie in the theater, in part due to some lukewarm reviews.  Well, those reviews were wrong.
  The movie starts with Bruce Willis talking on the phone about his Social Security check to a young woman at SS.  All of a sudden he is facing assassins.  And it goes on from there.  He recruits his old co-workers to help him.  In the process of dealing with high tech bad guys trying to kill him, a great time is had by all.  There's lots of shooting the bad guys, but somehow, we don't think about that.  This is not a transcendental film, just a great good time.  There is lots of comedy and action.  Get this DVD, play it on the biggest screen you have, and bring on the popcorn.

I just finished writing a review for another movie with the same title, which I accidentally rented with the intention of seeing this film! I love all kinds of movies, and I typically choose them depending on my mood. This fully delivered on my high expectations for an action/adventure film featuring a very impressive cast.

Morgan Freeman: what is there not to love about him? Bruce Willis brings so much life to every character he plays, and continually draws me in to not only choosing to watch, but also loving movies that I would never have considered before seeing "Die Hard." It would take me all night to even touch on the accomplishments of so many of the actors in this film.

One character I found very endearing was Ivan Simanov (Brian Cox), the long lost love of Victoria (Helen Mirren). He was so charming and I kept wondering who the actor was.

After I watched this, I immediately viewed the movie I had accidentally rented, Red (2008). It's a brutal, sad and touching story that I'll never forget. And then when I did my usual "actor search" afterward, I was totally blown away by the fact that Brian Cox was the star of that film.

If you have an appreciation for a broad spectrum of movie genres, watch them both!

was the star of .

Bought this on pre-order, assuming that a new release disc with HD video would have HD audio, just like every other BRD I have ever bought has, well the studio tried to pull a fast one, I assume to push people toward the more expensive SE disc, well I don't want all the extra cr*p, just HD audio and HD video, now they will get none of my $ and Amazon will pay for a return. Hopefully this deceitful tactic doesn't become the norm.

The cast is the best.  Always entertaining and for me a film I can just sit back and enjoy.  And it is a movie that I will watch repeatedly.  I have read several other lengthy good reviews and feel like most of them mirrored my thougths.  So I am keeping it simple.  I raved about it to family and friends when I went to see it and have been anxiously awaiting its release to DVD/BluRay so I can keep enjoying this movie for quite sometime.  For me definitely a 5 star movie!

RED (aka Retired Extremely Dangerous) is the moniker assigned to four retired CIA operatives, and if ever there were a film that demonstrates that folks beyond retirement age are still impressively functional, this is it.  The story is adapted from the graphic novel by Cully Hamner and Warren Ellis by screenwriters Jon and Erich Hoeber and directed with great style by Robert Schwentke.  But has been said often, it is the brilliant cast of experienced actors that makes this film one to treasure as simply splendid entertainment.

Frank Moses (Bruce Willis) is bored in his retirement; his only point of interest is a recurrent telephone conversation regarding his pension check with an equally bored government worker Sarah Ross (Mary-Louis Parker in a role that finally gives the range of her comedic talent its due!).  Their conversations are overheard by the CIA - William Cooper (Karl Urban) and his boss Cynthia Wilkes (Rebecca Pidgeon) - and Frank is marked for assassination. Bu told frank is wily and outsmarts and out shoots his intruders, escapes to take Sarah away from her boring desk job and a caper begins.  It seems there is a plot to uncover the USA Vice President's involvement in a Guatemala coups and Frank seeks out his old confreres - Joe (Morgan Freeman, living in a nursing home but very alert and involved with CIA thinking patterns), Marvin (John Malkovich, a half crazy near delusional but very fine marksman living in an underground hideaway), and Victoria (Helen Mirren, living the elegant life of teas and social activities while privately still taking contract jobs to knock off bad people).  At first Sarah is perplexed by the 'abduction' on the part of Frank, but soon becomes an involved participant in the drive to expose the secret of the Vice President.  The group engages a retired Russian spy (Brian Cox) who just happens to be Victoria's old boyfriend, and together these REDs use their skills, and brains, and great humor to achieve their goal. It is the old REDs against the young CIA agents that provides the tug of war that makes the film soar.

The cast sparkles in this richly colorful movie brimming over with CGI effects and impossible situations.  This is not a deep film but a movie that will entertain form the first frame to the final rather surprising episode.  It is a pleasure to simply watch the talents of Willis/Mirren/Freeman/Malkovich/Parker/Cox interact like so many pieces of a fine Swiss watch: they obviously love what they are asked to do!  Grady Harp, January 11
I liked the movie and I would like to buy it for my home movie collection.  I saw it at Walmart selling at a cheaper price than Amazon.

First and foremost, do NOT pay any attention to the 1 star reviews that are complaining that they couldn't take the time to check the difference between the reg. edition and the special edition so they were upset that the basic version was in Dolby sound and not HD. They aren't rating the movie at all. They are only rating it 1 star based off their own frustrations.
On to the movie:
Extras:
This is a fun to watch, a bit over the top but fun to watch film. In the behind the scenes they talk about how everyone brought their A-game and it made the others step up and be competative which made for a fun movie to make. You can see the sincerity in their interviews that even the top stars were enjoying working with the other stars in the film. At first, you may say, "There are very few special features. Why is this a special edition?" Well, the special edition has better audio/sound and I guess that's it but in the extras menu, it has only 3-4 extras but once you go into these options, it opens up many more short behind the scenes, interviews and much more. It looks like very little extras but there's more there than it looks like.
Movie:
By "over the top" I meant that anyone with any military or spec ops experience will say, "Um...you can't do that" at a few points but it's a movie and don't look too much into the somewhat exhagerated parts and you'll really enjoy this movie. One example is, you can NOT continually fire a 50cal machinegun without letting go of the trigger. You have to fire in 3-4 round bursts or you'll melt the barrel and it will seize up or worse. Small stuff like this might annoy some people but just watch it and enjoy.
There are a lot of great one-liners and Malkovich (Martin) gets some of the best lines. Although Bruce Willis (ex-CIA) can be called the star, Morgan Freeman (ex-CIA), John Malkovich (ex-CIA), Helen Mirren (ex-MI6), Brian Cox (ex-KGB?), Karl Urban (CIA) and many more are all written so well that they all steal scenes at one point or another.
Karl Urban is the younger CIA agent that is on the trail of the retired (RED) operatives and as the movie progresses, I found it very well written that even though he is slowly learning that maybe these guys aren't the bad guys, he does his job no matter what. He still chases them, looks deeper and deeper into the situation until he finally finds out the truth.

Got to put im my few words about the blu-ray edition of RED. There must be a few different versions out there. People spending twelve bucks and expecting a top blu-ray release and transfer...go rent it instead! Does the phrase "you get what you pay for" sound familiar? The 'cheaper' movie only is not to be aimed at people that are into high quality, top notch blu-ray transfers. This is aimed at the people who 'just want to see the movie in other than DVD format'. This explains the single layer pressing with non-lossy audio. For a few extra bucks get the special edition and quit crying already!! You are giving this product a bad rap because you make bad choices by getting the cheapest version out there. The special edition I have is a flipper disc, which I know are trouble, with DVD on the flip-side. The blu-ray played without a glitch. Don't know if the special edition Amazon offers includes DVD or not, but I do know that the special edition is pressed at a much higher bit-rate than the cheap movie only disc. And it does include a DTS-HD soundtrack that really rocks!!! Plus it has great special features (including an all access pass).
So don't be mislead by the bad reviews of the movie-only edition and get this special edition and leave your brains at the door and you will have fun!
Enjoy!!

I've been a fan of Bruce Willis for some time now. From his first major appearance on MOONLIGHTING through the DIE HARD films, I've made a point to see his films when they are released. When I heard that he was starring in RED, based on the comic book of the same name, I was anxious to see how it turned out. And while it plays loose with the source material, it ends up being one of my favorite films from last year.

The story revolves around Frank Moses (Willis), a retired "Agency" assassin living a boring life that has become far too routine for him. To pass the time he calls Sarah Ross (Mary Louise Parker), the woman who handles payments to retired employees of a company she only knows as legit with no clue as to his past. Each month he calls to tell her the check didn't arrive, even though it did, and the two have a conversation. Both are bored and lonely and strike up a phone friendship.

Unfortunately for Frank the "Agency" monitors all of its ex-employees designated RED (Retired Extremely Dangerous) and don't take kindly to them making consistent phone calls. Rather than assume nothing despicable is going on, they're more prone to think secrets are being leaked or some other nefarious plot is in the works. So they send a strike team to take out Frank one night. But as his designated retirement status claims, Frank is not someone you should mess with. The team is taken out and Frank is on the run.

His first stop is to find Sarah who he realizes he has accidentally placed in danger. Rescuing her and with her still not quite ready to believe his story, they head out to find other members of his old team. Like conspiracy minded Marvin Boggs who thinks everyone is out to get him played fantastically by John Malkovich. Then Joe Matheson (Morgan Freeman) who welcomes the chance to escape his retirement home for some action like the old days. And finally there is Victoria (Helen Mirren), set up in peaceful tranquility...with the exception of taking on the occasional assassination.

Brought back together by circumstances the team is on the move to find out who it was that authorized the hit and why. On their tail is "Agency" man William Cooper (Karl Urban), a top notch agent who could be Frank's match. If it wasn't for the fact that Frank taught Cooper's trainer everything he knew...but not all that Frank knew.

Crosses and double crosses flow throughout the story as the team follows one lead to another in an attempt to find out just who is behind the uproar. Everyone from a weapons manufacturer (Richard Dreyfuss) to the Vice President become suspects but it isn't until the final moments that we discover just who the culprit is.

Along the way there are plenty of explosions, jokes and hand to hand combat moments that should keep Willis and action fans sitting on the edge of their seats. By the last reel you'll find yourself wishing that the movie hadn't ended and that another was on the way. Thank goodness the rumor mill has it that their planning a sequel.

The action is non-stop, the effects are top notch and the acting is some of the best I've seen. To me the best acting doesn't involve the ability to simply say your lines in the most dramatic way possible. Instead, the best acting is when you completely forget the fact that you're watching a movie, that the person performing is an actor and you totally believe that for two hours they ARE that person. Such are the performances by all involved here.

But best of all with this movie is the fact that for 111 minutes you are entertained. And in the long run isn't that what it's all about? No, this film will not find most involved nominated for any Oscars but the truth is that some of the most entertaining films made never do. Instead they find fans who watch the film over and over again. This is one of those movies, a film that I for one feel I could watch more than three times and never be bored with. And that makes it a movie worth watching.
Reminds me of "Sneakers" with guns.  Laughed, smiled and rooted for the good guys or are they bad guys?

The strongest part of this movie is the cast. Its really good to see this group of actors playing together and they do a good job with what they have. When you first start to watch you think the movie is a serious action movie, but you soon realize there are a lot of comedic elements to the overall story. Some are funny, especially when it involves John Malkovich, while the rest detract from the movie. Its almost like the movie cant quite figure out whether it wants to be serious or funny, and mixing the two doesn't quite work.

The story itself is nothing special, but the talented cast does a good job with it. The special effects are pretty good, though I questioned how they made going after the vice president look so easy. Overall RED is a good movie to watch if you just want to see a decent action movie with a few laughs, but don't expect much beyond that.
wont think twice to check the audio format since its bluray thinking your getting FULL HD content WRONG!!!! whos idea was this?????? SUMMIT!!! I won't even rent it!!!!!!!!!!!!

Very disappointed  in this version I did not know you had to by the special edition so you could get DTS High def version. You only get the plain Dolby digital version with the single disk. I think Amazon could have made that clear.

Just FYI

To begin, I rated this movie five stars not because its one of the best movies I've ever seen, but because, in my opinion, its better than so many of the movies released in 2010.

Compared to the other oldie action movie of 2010, The Expendables, RED is a clear winner.
As others have said; we know, and probably mostly love, the cast. Being British, the delightful performances of Helen Mirren and Brian Cox were going to make this a winner for me, and Karl Urban always impresses me.

Philip French in The Guardian (a British newspaper) reviewed RED and said 'This is painting by numbers for people who have trouble with mental arithmetic.'  No doubt if, like Mr French, you only enjoy watching obscure Kenyan arthouse movies then RED isn't for you.

There's a measured amount of comedy, a great fight scene between Willis and Urban, and will probably be remembered for Helen Mirren in a white ballgown firing the belt fed machine gun.

The DVD release is decent, but I wish they'd put a little effort into making some limited editions for us collectors.

I wish Amazon would keep reviews of the blu-ray release seperate from DVD reviews, although those of us buying DVDs can laugh this time around as the blu-ray buying fools pay almost double for a movie only release with mere DVD quality sound (those 1 star reviews).

Everyone can relax. I was correct and should have been refunded the $3 and Amazon finally admitted it. You are all raving about me giving a movie one star when it was Amazon I was mad at.  Don't you think you all are being just as big of jerks as you say I am?  Going on and on, raving about a poor rating for a stupid movie. Get a life!!

I ordered this item on 1/24/11.  About 15 minutes after I ordered it, Amazon lowered the price by $3.  I tried to cancel it and reorder, but the site had already locked me out. I figured I would be billed the current $12.99 that was advertised.  NOT SO, I was billed $15.99 and when I wrote to say that I thought I should get a $3 refund, I got a snotty little email back stating essentially that they didn't care if I went elsewhere to purchase my items, they were not refunding the difference.  I have spent thousands of dollars on Amazon in the past year, but being a good customer doesn't make any difference to them.  They don't care about you and don't let them tell you the do. They have now admitted that there is a pre order price quarantee, that the person responding to me was incorrect, and the $3 was atomatically refunded today.

I just saw this movie on Comcast Ondemand and I gotta say it was a blast Bruce Willis,and Morgan freeman and John Malkovich as Ex Cia in retirement who wined up on a hit list and that is where the fun begins through the list and turns you will have a ball and as for Helen Mirren what can I say except she is still a babe,she takes to this movie certain Jenesaisquois, all I know is they all still have all, this movie is worth the money if nothing else for Helen Mirren for she is one fine looking women....................
This edition of the film only has lossy Dolby Digital sound.  You have to buy the special edition to get a lossless DTS Master soundtrack.  Shame on Summit!
Lack of a lossless HD audio track is such a big turn off.  Never would I think to double check the audio formats on a Bluray.  Shame on Summit Entertainment!

After an attack at home Frank Moses (Willis) recruits his old CIA buddies for help in revenge.  Using all the tricks he knows Moses hunts down the person responsible for the attack while trying to avoid a tenacious CIA agent trying to stop him.  This is another movie that falls into a common trap.  Assemble an All-Star cast, realize everyone will watch for cast, slack off on rest.  To me it feels like the bigger the stars put together the bigger the dissapointment.  I'm not saying this is a bad movie, it's just very average.  With the cast assembled (and the Golden Globe nomination for Best Picture) I was expecting hilarious.  It had funny parts, but a little flat in some areas.  It sounds like I'm bashing it but it was a good movie.  I was just expecting more.  You will definately have a good time watching, just don't get your hopes too high. The best part of the movie hands down is John Malkovich, watch for him if nothing else.  I give it a B.

Would I watch again? - If it came on TV

The movie is a quality no-brain popcorn flick.  However the blu-ray release comes in two flavors, barebones and special edition.  This barebones (movie-only) edition has lossy quality audio most commonly found on DVDs.  With the conception of blu-ray two lossless audio codecs were introduced DTS-HD MA and Dolby TrueHD, the special edition utilizes the DTS-HD MA codec.  The lossy audio makes this product a 1 star, blu-ray is HD and putting a product out that isn't both HD audio and HD video is an attempt at fooling the customer; shame on Summit.  The special edition would get a 4/5 star from me as it has HD audio, DTS-HD MA (just an FYI for those reading this review when it shows up on the special edition blu-ray page).

Recently I read a great metaphor for lossy versus lossless compression algorithms.  Basically lossy is how you can take a photograph in its RAW format and compress it into another form such as JPG.  The file becomes smaller because bits are thrown away, the image still looks good enough when viewed in certain ways but those bits cannot ever be retrieved. Lossless compression is like when you ZIP a file on your computer, when you unzip the file all the bits are still there.  So basically lossless audio codecs allow all the audio information to be present for your system to utilize them, making them sound more definitive and crisp because all the bits are there!

My one star rating applies to this blu-ray release only. I saw the film in theaters an it is entertainingly enough. But Summit studio apparently created this "not so Special Edition" primarily for the rental market and also for the budget market. It is barebones, almost no extra features, but even worse only has DVD quality Dolby Digital Audio as it is only on a 25GB single disc and there wasn't enough room to include much else. You have to buy the Special Edition to get lossless DTS-HD Master Audio and all the extra features. Shame on the studio for even releasing a blu-ray without the blu-ray standard of high-def picture AND high-def sound.

This was a very funny and thus a fun movie to watch. Mary-Louise Parker and the duct tape scene was priceless. I can't wait to see this one again and again as the cast did a great job and made a very funny, fun entertaining film. A+

What's the selling point of RED? Stars you like doing stuff you like, mainly shooting things. At this, the film does very well. And fortunately, the things it doesn't do very well don't detract from the film that much.

Granted, the plot is incomprehensible, and the supposed twists at the end will have you thoroughly scratching your head, but most of the main plot points at least have an interesting action setpiece surrounding it. Also, I had a big problem with Morgan Freeman in this film, as he gets second billing, but is in the film a grand total of 10 minutes. He's good during those 10 minutes, but it's little more than a glorified extended cameo, since he doesn't really factor into much of anything very much. I mean, was he too busy filming Thick as Thieves or any of the other myriad straight-to-dvd trash he's been involved with in the past decade? Sorry, just had to get those off my chest.

Still, RED mostly makes it up with a great cast and creative action. It's hard to tell what Bruce Willis phoning in a performance is anymore, but here he's just Bruce Willis, and the results are pretty nice. He's still believable as an elite assassin type who can best men half his age, and he pulls the romantic aspects of the plot fine as well. Which brings me to Mary-Louise Parker who while I've never been a particular fan of, does a good job as the cute government customer service girl dragged into this crazy conspiracy. She's charming and funny, and while she isn't exactly asked to do a lot, she does a very good job with what she has. Helen Mirren and Brian Cox are appropriately cute together. Karl Urban sounds exactly like Dr. McCoy as a CIA agent, but he's actually quite likable despite some of the more cliched aspects of his character.

Still, none of them quite reach the level of John Malkovich having a helluva good time as the LSD-dosed paranoid agent who serves about 85% of the comedic beats of this action comedy. He really gives a lot to the role, giving the appropriate amount of crazy to make this character, who at one point charges at the Vice-President with a fake bomb strapped to him, really funny and memorable. He has a lot of great lines, he has some good action beats, and he's given a lot of great stuff to play off of, mainly his pink pig.

As for the action, it has a lot of creative over-the-top sequences, never too far apart, to keep you thoroughly entertained throughout. There's the awesome Bruce Willis stepping out of a moving/spinning car while shooting a guy scene, but the scene taking place with a bunch of cargo crates probably takes the cake. It's fairly short, but it exemplifies everything to like about the movie. There's general craziness (using a gun as a bat to toss back a live grenade), very creative and satisfying moments (the grenade launcher hitting the first guy was particularly great), and then of course you have the explosions and a good Malkovich one-liner to top everything off.

Overall, if you know what to expect, and it's really not that hard to know, you should have a pretty enjoyable time watching a bunch of older actors kick butt. It's pretty accessible to most anybody if you want a good date movie, action movie or comedy, and judging by the reaction in my theater audience, it's also quite the crowd-pleaser. So, if you want a bunch of Retired, but Extremely Dangerous people to invade your screen for a good time, put in RED.

Another action packed ride from him with plot twists at every corner!  I thought the phone romance was sweet, and the fact that he had to abduct her to save her life (while putting it at risk) was also sweet, and crazy!  It was a nice and crazy high risk romance, just like the ones she was always reading anyways!  I half expected the ending to be her "book", lol.  But the movie was top notch,primo actors all around, nice storyline, lots of exploxions and a decent storylines.  You can't go wrong with Willis or Freeman!  Definitly pick it up if you haven't already, worth the watch!

I have enjoyed the resurgence of legitimate actors filming action movies.  Action movies aren't high art, but having the likes of Helen Mirren, Brian Cox, and Morgan Freeman make any film better.  Their roles made the film fun, unpredictable, and satisfying.  The action scenes are over the top, but they don't overshadow the characters.  This is where The Expendables missed the boat.  Highly recommend this movie!

Hadn't even seen the previews for this, but so glad we went to see it! Great acting job done by all, great action (my personal favorite is when he steps out of the spinning police car!!) and VERY funny!
A totally fun, action-packed 2 hours. The whole cast is fantastic and John Malkovich's special brand of crazy is awesome to watch. Highly recommended!

I was horrified to see that this atrocious film averages a four star rating. I felt obliged to provide an honest and critical account of what must easily rank as the worst movie of the year, if not the decade. It just goes to show how Hollywood has gradually eroded our capacity for critical appraisal and evaluative thought. This awful movie is one enormous cliche based around a series of pathetic and obvious jokes that sound like they were written by a seven year old. In some cases the script is so vapid that the other characters respond to what appears to be an attempted witty one-liner by staring blankly at each other. It is so far fetched and absurd that it is not even entertaining in a weak and obvious Benny Hill sort of vein (not that I like Benny Hill).

It is astonishing that there are adults out there who uncritically lap up the drivel that "great" actors sign their names to, just because of who they are. Yes, Helen Mirren is a superb actor who has played some magnificent roles. That doesn't excuse the appalling tripe dished up in this dreadful corker. Contrary to the beliefs of her gulllible and undiscerning fans out there, great actors are not infallible or super-human. I am not generally a huge fan of Bruce Willis and I am sorry to say he did nothing in this movie to alter my opinion. He was smug and uninspiring, but at least he was consistent - there was no evidence of any acting at any stage in the movie.

It does make me feel all warm and fuzzy inside to know that people thought this was a "fun" movie, despite the fact that it was mindless, predictible, pointless and boring. It gives me hope to know that I could scrape together a half-arsed excuse for a movie with a preposterous plot, bland performances and vacuous script. I would then stock it full of 'big names' and make millions of dollars out of it by selling it to the unsuspecting public who ostensibly accept anything that the big names regurgitate into their laps.

A victim of my Scottish heritage, I rarely walk out of movies and thereby waste my investment in the ticket price. However I was compelled to walk out of Red in order to avoid the zombifying effects of this cinematic black-hole. In fact, I could feel my brain-cells self-immolating in protest faster than the vast quantities of sugar I was eating to try and stay awake could destroy them. It is almost criminal that I was charged money to watch Red. The lowest Circle of Hell would be one vast 360 screen playing Red over and over again for all eternity.
A great movie.  Lots of action and humor.  Great cast.  DVD doesn't indicate any outakes - - what, no outtakes? - - there should be just because of the actors.
WENT TO THE MOVIES TO SEE THIS.IT WAS TO ME THE BEST MOVIE OF 2010. LOTS OF ACTION ,SOME COMEDY AND LOVE.

October 2010. If movies about social networking sites and mishmashes are what passes for "A truly cinematic experience" nowadays, I guess you could count me out. That is, until I noticed that a movie I never saw any trailers for, and full of stars, called RED was out. Easily taken in before I read anything about its plot, I went and saw it. That blind watch I'm definitely proud of!

RED is cliched in terms of story- a retired agent has his house destroyed by a secret agency and makes for the next state, picking up some friends along the way in an all-out, over-the-top action adventure. But as cliche as it is, RED is also just fun. We have Morgan Freeman, Bruce Willis (in the tough guy role as usual), the chick from Weeds, Helen Mirren- all are fantastic. There's plenty of over-the-top action that's fun, it's hilarious, and overall it's a fun movie if all you ask for is just some pure escapist fun.

In the end, RED is definitely not art or Oscar material, but it is one of the most fun movies of 2010, and recommended for some pure entertainment!

I love spy stories, but I was reluctant to see this movie in the theaters because I thought the comedic aspect of it would make it a disaster.  Boy, was I wrong.  This film, with it's awesome cast, is the perfect blend of comedy and action and a must-have for any spy fan. Definitely grab this one.

this movie is awesome. i love this movie. this movie has my all time favorite actors in it and you can't go any better. this movie is awesome. the actors are great and so is the story and the action is non stop. this movie is awesome. if you have not seen this movie then i recommedn you do

In the barren wasteland of fall movies "based on true stories" about social networking and such BS mish-mash movies, I was left with Jackass 3D and RED.  I wanted to see Jackass initially, but I decided to wait for the DVD.  I still liked the guys who maim themselves for my entertainment and wanted to support them, but the 3D aspect was a little much.

I was told by two people that RED was a great ride and very fun.  I knew the people I was speaking with and I knew their views on movies.  I went and saw it.  Bruce Willis is very John McClane-ish and the movie was a blast!

Morgan Freeman and John Malkovich were great!

Karl Urban was a great addition.  I look forward to seeing him in other roles outside of Star Trek again.  Especially, the new Judge Dredd film.

Ernest Borgnine was a very welcome addition to the cast.  It was good to see him acting again.

You want a fun 1980s/1990s action feel of a fun pop corn movie?  Then go see RED.

Retirement sucks, as anyone can tell you.  For former black-ops CIA agents, the inactivity would drive a person insane.  Bruce Willis (Frank Moses) is suffering from that insanity.  He's a loner, his house lacking all the essential necessities to make it a home, and he's bored out of his mind.  He doesn't know how to blend into the neighborhood, pitifully viewing the landscape for what is expected. His desperation, his loneliness, and the inactivity of retirement leads him to tear up his retirement check and call an ever patient, equally lonely customer service agent in Kansas City.  The conversations with Sarah (Parker) are the highlight of his month and, through these conversations, he attempts to become more 'normal'.  Someone should tell Frank that a man reading a romance novel is not considered 'normal'.
This retirement that eats at Frank's nerves is shattered when a hit squad attacks his house in the middle of the night.  Frank, as skilled as ever, kills the assassins.  Decades of training leads him to believe they have tapped his phone lines, and he's off to Kansas to save his phone buddy Sarah. Her reluctance to be saved (imagine someone you've only ever spoken to being in your home when you come back from an excrutiatingly boring date!) causes Frank to kidnap her.

Sarah goes on a wild ride with Frank while he attempts to discover who is trying to kill him and why.  He travels cross country to find the members of his old black ops team, who are all equally retired and bored to death. Meanwhile, the viewer discovers the CIA is the machine behind the attempt on Frank's life.

Morgan Freeman (Joe Black) is at his suave self, living in a retirement community and suffering from stage 4 cancer.  John Malkovich (LSD paranoid Marvin) hides in tunnels and carries a stuffed pig under his arm.  Helen Mirren proves that mature women can be sexy carrying a high powered rifle,and arranging flowers in a Better Homes and Garden style home. Her comment about taking an 'odd job on the side' still makes me laugh.

This is an all-star cast of superb actors that deliver an action-packed, fast paced, comedic, and highly entertaining film.  The twists and turns are thrilling. I loved every moment of it and it proves that even the retirees have a magnetic bit of life still left in them.

RED

STARRING: Bruce Willis, Mary-Louise Parker, John Malkovich, Karl Urban, Helen Mirren, Morgan Freeman, Richard Dreyfuss, Brian Cox, Rebecca Pidgeon and Julian McMahon

WRITTEN BY: Jon Hoeber and Erich Hoeber; based on the graphic novel by Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner

DIRECTED BY: Robert Schwentke

Rated: PG - 13
Genre: Action / Comedy
Release Date: 15 October 2010
Review Date: 08 November 2010

Recently numerous movies have shown us great actors can make ridiculous material wildly entertaining. MacGruber, Machete and now Red have all been absurdly obnoxious, but their cast has kept them in the realm of the best films of 2010.

Let's start with THEE action star himself, Bruce Willis. Surprisingly enough, he's not a cop this time! He's Frank Moses, an ex CIA operative being hunted down by a league of bad guys who make Swiss cheese out of his house via machineguns. Naturally Frank walks away unscathed and we are left wondering: who would send so many dudes to shoot up a house rather than just one to blow it up?

The answer to that is found in Red's tone, which is: because it looks cooler. The charm of Red is that it knows it's absurd but it wants to be, and it also knows how to be absurd but cleverly entertaining at the same time. Oh, and if you are wondering why it's called Red, well that stands for Retired Extremely Dangerous; see what I mean?

Frank has been flirting over the phone with a phone operator named Sarah (Mary-Louise Parker) and in doing so does two things an action hero can never do without serious consequences: he speaks on an unsecured line and he falls in love with a beautiful woman whom the bad guys will inevitably capture and hold at bay.

This happens of course, but it's not the chain of events that holds our attention, so much as the journey we take with the characters in getting to those must-have action moments. For instance, not having time to explain that more bad guys are about to break down her door and kill her, Frank kidnaps Sarah; and this is their first meet I might add. Then they head off on an amusing road trip in search of assistance and information from a league of Frank's old counterparts who include Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich and Helen Mirren.
