Next to the gnarly bad-ass-ness that is Bruce Willis in anything he does - the Malkovich character was my favorite. Malkovich plays Marvin Boggs, a paranoid gun toting hermit who lives in a kind of underground fall out shelter, accessed only by - well, I can't reveal that; it's too funny and I've said too much already. Just know that you will love Malkovich's off the wall and canny portrayal, and that he gets 90 percent of the laughs. Shocker, I know.

Government pensioner Frank Moses (Bruce Willis) lives a dull life in a quiet suburb of Cleveland.  His principal amusement is romancing a bored pension clerk named Sarah (a superbly cast Mary Louise Parker) over the phone.  One night, a squad of black-ops agents breaks in.  Frank mops the floor with them, revealing astonishing black-ops skills of his own.  On the run, he kidnaps the rather willing Sarah.  Turns out Frank Moses is "retired-extremely dangerous" and the CIA, for some reason, wants him dead.

Frank hunts up some old comrades (Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich, and Helen Mirren) to find out why they are all being targeted.  Frank will also get help from an old Russian adversary (Brian Cox) and an old records keeper (Earnest Borgnine in one of his last film roles).  Frank and his buddies will have to stay one step ahead the very capable young CIA operative William Cooper (Karl Urban).

At the heart of the story is a ridiculously complicated and hilarious plot full of black helicopters and corrupt officials.  The fun is in watching a nicely matched collection of gifted actors roll through an action-comedy while reeling off Cold War jokes, clichés, and sight gags.  Highly recommended as good fun.

genre. A stellar cast of, shall we say, senior citizens? Led by Bruce Willis playing, Frank Moses, a wry, Retired Extremely Dangerous agent who still has his skill set. The CIA is trying to kill him, collegue, Morgan Freeman & others for some unpleasantness that occurred in Central America years ago. So they set out to find out who & why. Early on Frank acquires a younger girl friend played by Mary Louise Parker. She is unwilling at first but they are trying to kill her too so she becomes an enthusiastic participant. The trail led to the vice president who turns out to be a master-mind criminal. So it is decided to kill him & prevent him from becoming president. They enlist killer John Malkevich & retired assassin for hire Helen Mirren. I've never seen such a sexy senior citizen manning a machine gun. She's the #1 reason I went to see this movie. They all ourageously ham it up but they are so good the plot hardly matters. Massive mayhem ensues as the bodies pile up. The violence is a bit cartoonish & this will never be mistaken for art.
  It is really escapist fare, highly entertaining & you get your money's worth as it runs 111 miutes, long for this type movie. I lost myself monentarily while watching it. It won't be long after it's run that it will be on dvd /blueray. Excellent.

I couldn't help but compare "RED" to the Coen Brothers' "Burn After Reading".  Both are comedies centered around preposterous CIA plots, and both feature John Malkovich.  For "Retired, Extremely Dangerous" I only lament that the script spent more time setting up a ridiculous plot than giving its' A-List cast dialogue worthy of 3 Oscars (Morgan Freeman,Helen Mirren and Richard Dreyfuss) and 2 Emmies (Brian Cox and Malkovich).  Mary-Louise Parker gives one of the best performances in the film as a government clerk who gets dragged into the life and death spy game only because Bruce Willis' retired character takes a shine to her.  Karl Urban gets the thankless role as the CIA henchman leading the black ops team trying to exterminate Willis and company.

The plot is entirely too ridiculous to be taken seriously, but the film is also a little flat taken strictly as a comedy.  I'll split it down the middle and say it's worth watching if it comes up while you're on a plane, or a rental on a "we're bored" night, if only to watch these excellent actors look like they're having a quite good time.
This movie has several of my favorite things... Bruce Willis, CIA flavor, lots of action, and a light, humorous tone... I have signed up to be notified when it comes out on DVD... LOVED this movie!
It was a really enjoyable movie. We recommend this movie highly. Excellent fun to escape to.
This movie provides a fun experience and great entertainment.  A list of grade A actors having a fantastic time.

Who cares if it is completely preposterous, Red is great fun all the way.  Bruce Willis, Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich, Richard Dreyfuss and Helen Mirren all increased their net worth through signing up for this movie, and all have a great time.  Several here have argued that it is Malkovich who steals the movie, and when he first appears dressed in some kind of leafed out camouflage, he's off to a great start.  But he has by now taken out the patent on controlled psycho persona, so my vote for most fun goes to Helen Mirren.  It isn't every day that you get to watch The Queen wield heavy weapons with aplomb from a leafy Maryland retirement house, but she does it and makes smashing entertainment with it.  Never mind the plot -- it has something to do with the vice-president or perhaps the evil mastermind (Dreyfuss) manipulating the vice-president somehow subverting the whole of the CIA to their nefarious ends -- because Red is played for entertainment and laughs, not plot sense.  It is a great way to spend a Saturday night, in theaters or at home.

Sometimes you watch a movie and sense that the actors had as much fun as the audience. This is one of those. Won't change the world, but it is a pleasant way to spend a couple of hours. You'll have a good time.

Bruce Willis may be old but he sure doesn't act like he's over the hill.  Karl Urban's performance didn't disappoint either. We saw this movie yesterday and all us were of the consensus that it was entertaining and definitely worth getting on Blu-ray.

In matters of taste there is no dispute and by giving this abomination a 2 star rating I'm bound to arouse the ire of those who love Bruce Willis, Action-Adventure etc.  Nevertheless, I personally think this film stinks.  In many ways the plot is a rip-off of the equally lousy 'Shooter'.  In both films impossible violence against the CIA and the U.S. Government is justified by the slaughter of vative villages--in Ethiopia ['Shooter'] and in Guatemala ['Red'].

Anyway, it seems that Willis, Freeman etc. [senior citizens all] are more lethal, dangerous and well-armed than were 50 Clint Eastwoods.  These guys are real terrors.  They mow down equally well-armed and far more numerous CIA men without getting hit themselves [of course].  Standard Action-Adventure fare, if you think about it.  Shell casings pile up in their thousands and the dead in their hundreds.  Willis is the 'most interesting man alive.' to quote a well-known commercial.

To make the Hollywood point even further, a Russian agent/KGB is a terrific guy who helps our guys against the evil U.S.  Drip, drip, drip.  He always shows up where he isn't expected and just in the nick of time.  Amazing.

Obviously this dreck cost quite a lot of money to make--well-known actors and plenty of special effects.  The film's lack of any real quality must rest directly on the shoulders of brain-dead writers and their director/producer promoters.  Then again, maybe they aren't that brain dead.  Some kids, who claimed this movie was 'great', got me to buy their tickets.  I was an unwitting accomplice to the subversion of our youth.  Shame on me.

I mean, anything that features Dame Mirren, an elegant evening gown, and a .50 cal machine gun can't be all bad. Once you stop taking it seriously (something sure to happen early on), it's a riot. The basic message is a boomer ego-stroke: "Don't mess with the old guys." Unfortunately, that's what happens. Retired CIA agents start dying at an alarming rate. It turns out that the decedents all worked on the one particular mission - one that Our Heroes worked on as well. So, when the hit men come after the hit men, the chase is on. And, as it progresses it reaches higher and higher into the halls of government. You know, the usual. In this movie, the fun is all in getting there. Bruce Willis's wise-cracking plays well against John Malkovich's slightly deranged character, Morgan Freeman's easy-going character balances them both, and Helen Mirren adds a touch of class. Then there's Mary-Louise Parker's character, Sarah, in a role like Diaz's in Knight and Day only not as ridiculous. Keep your ears open for the one-liners. There were enough times I was the only one in the theater laughing that I might have been the only one listening, too. OK, maybe this isn't one for the ages. It's a heck of a way to spend a Saturday night, though. -- wiredweird

When I first saw the previews to the movie, I was honestly unsure if I wanted to see it only because the movie seemed to be scripted to former CIA agents that want revenge. While it is fine to have such a script, I was wondering how exciting it was going to be. Then they showed the preview of John Malkovich saying "Old my (you know what) shooting at a younger assasin who seemed to be in for the shock of her life after realizing that he had more fighting ability than initially realized. It was then I decided to see it because something about that scene made me realize that the movie was going to be more eventful than what I was seeing in the trailer. Fortunately, I am glad that I decided to go with this feeling. This movie has a strong all star cast of actors and actresses featuring Bruce Willis, Helen Mirren, Morgan Freeman, John Malkovich who end up going on a "adventure/preserving their life mission" after finding out that very powerful people in government want them dead for some reason. From my perspective, The plot was a combination of dark comedy and action. The two actors that stood out the most for me in the movie were John Malkovich and Helen Mirren.  Helen Mirren stood out because she plays a strong and self confident former CIA operative who is ready at a moment's notice to go on "the odd jobs here and there" whenever she is needed. I like that she plays a very assertive and powerful person who knows what she wants. She also seems like the type of person that is comfortable and happy with herself in real-life from the strong performance she gave in the movie. I am a college student who is obviously from a different generation than she is, but I am inspired by Helen's example and intend to be an extremely self-confident person by the time that I reach the life stage that she is in now.  I enjoyed John Malkovich's performance very much because he played a gifted but extremely paranoid former operative that was frequently looking over his shoulder for perceived threats in a very powerful and with the right amount of forceful manner. As it turns out, his paranoia many times is justified. He really adds excitement and humor to the movie in his role as a talented but guarded former CIA operative. The best indicators I can say is if you like your movies with a mix of dark comedy, action, drama, and suspense then chances are good that you are going to enjoy this movie.

I never read the comic books, so I couldn't compare it. I didn't really like this movie as well as I thought I would. There were a few decent action scenes that caught my attention. The rest of the story just has them talking. Frank Moses, Joe Matheson, Marvin Boggs, and Victoria are retired CIA agents. They are soon targeted for assassination. They must team up and work together to figure out who wants to kill them and why. Frank brings along a woman named Sarah who is his 'sorta-kinda' girlfriend. Don't expect too much while seeing this movie. If you want a bland action film to only see maybe once or twice in your life, you might like RED!!!

This movie has it all. It's got:

- Lots of action. Even though Bruce Willis is playing an older, retired guy, he's still got the goods. He's completely convincing. The rest of the cast delivers as well.

- Funny moments - While it's not a continual thing, there are plenty of funny and light moments, with a few of laugh out louds. Willis is the master of action flick funny, and John Malkovich was surprisingly hilarious. The rest of the cast contributed well as straight guys.

- Romance - Bruce Willis and Mary-Louise Parker really work. I don't want to ruin any surprises, but lets say it starts out and ends in a surprising way, and they had good chemistry.

- Character development - Surprisingly well done for an action flick. Each character was really defined, and you get to care about them.

- Suspense - It was really a good story, and well written. It was full of twists and surprises, with plenty of "edge of your seat" moments.

- Outstanding cast - The star power in this movie was blinding. These people really shined. They're not stars for nothing. Each person was fantastic in their role.

The beginning of the movie dragged just a bit, but once it took off, it really flew.

It was a really enjoyable movie. We recommend this movie highly, however please don't bring your young kids as one family in the theater did. There's too much violence for children.

"Red" (Retired Extremely Dangerous) is an action/adventure/comedy about four former CIA operatives who have never quite lost their addiction to adrenaline.  During the opening credits, we observe a bored-looking Bruce Willis, who plays tough-as-nails Frank Moses, eating breakfast, working out, checking his mail, and chatting with a woman over the phone named Sarah Ross (Mary-Louise Parker) whom he would like to get to know better.  It is Christmas season and every house is festively decorated.  Suddenly, all heck breaks loose as a team of assassins closes in on Moses's house with enough firepower to destroy a city block.  Who is targeting Frank and why?

Eventually, Moses teams up with his old buddies, Joe (Morgan Freeman), Marvin (John Malkovich), and the still sexy Victoria (Helen Mirren), all of whom are highly-trained former operatives with an encyclopedic knowledge of firearms and explosives.  Since Frank has shown an interest in Sarah, she is dragged into the mess.  They criss-cross the country trying to elude their pursuers and find out who is behind all of the mayhem.

This kind of satirical movie is extremely difficult to pull off.  Director Robert Schwentke tries not to wink at the audience too much, and the old pros play their parts amusingly, only occasionally going too far over the top.  The script by Jon and Erich Hoeber, based on a graphic novel, is insubstantial, and there are quite a few scenes of cartoonish violence.  Since the screenplay is not exactly Shakespearean in scope, you will need to put your brain on hold.  So, why should you see this film?  If you have a free afternoon or evening and do not mind a bit of escapism, "Red" is an enjoyable diversion.  Willis and his colleagues seem to be having a great time playing off one another and poking fun at the kind of character whom Bruce Willis portrayed so well during his salad days.
